title: How does society influence and shape individuals? - Quora

response.answer_text: Unless you are raised by wolves or in a closet or basement, and even then, to the extent that genes are influenced by social evolution, everything that influences and shapes individuals comes from society. Humans seem to do better in groups (societies) than as isolated individuals. We are pretty good at cooperation, and the better we cooperate, the more powerful and successful we become as a species, and the more our genetic heritage reinforces the strength of the relationship between society and the individual. Without a society of humans, there couldn’t be individual humans. We wouldn’t be alive. At the very least, at least until human cloning is standard, we all need the genetic material from a man and a woman in order to come into existence. The minimum number of people to form a society seems to be two — a parent and a child (unless the wolves really can raise children, but then, that’s a society, too). Most of us are born into societies made of far more than two people. So our behavior is noticed by thousands of people, directly. We get feedback from those people in many ways. Some of the feedback is directly related to us, and is provided specifically with the intention to tell us how to be human. Most other feedback we get is from the body language of strangers or people less well known to us or from their words and other reactions, and this all helps us figure out what to do in order to survive. I think it safe to say that without society, the vast majority of human beings could not survive. There might be a few “My Side of the Mountain” loners who can live off the land and need no contact with other humans, but I bet they still need some kind of contact with living beings. For most of us, though, society is the life force. Being able to fit in well enough to survive is essential, and so most people learn to do that to some degree or another. And, like other animals, our ability to pass our genes on to succeeding generations depends, in part, on our status within society. The more status we have, the better we can prepare our children to survive or the more access we have to what is necessary to reproduce. I’d say that we aren’t human without human society. We don’t make sense as isolated individuals and we can’t survive as isolated individuals. In that sense, it makes sense to see humankind as an organism made up of cooperating individual humans, the same way as individual humans are made up of cooperating cells. The cells can’t exist without the other cells they cooperate with. Humans can’t exist without the other humans we cooperate with. If we can’t cooperate with others, it’s much more likely we will be excluded from society, which is a sentence to death without reproduction. So most people are completely influenced and shaped by society. There is no way to overstate the influence that society has on individuals.

Several factors are involved. How susceptible is the individual to outside input? (Sophisticated, or accepting of any input). How informed the person is about what is true vs. what is a lie. How persuasive is the argument: Said by a powerful trusted spokesperson? Or said by someone who is disrespected in general.How close is the event/situation to a person's immediate life: In their home, or invisibly happening 10,000 miles away? How much time does the person have to discern or make an important decision? Is it urgent and immediate, or do they have time to check facts and other sources?How impressionable is the person? Are they soft like tissue paper (highly absorbent or like hard steel (nothing penetrates, their mind is made up). How dramatic is the message? Is it highly impactful like a tsunami on your doorstep? Or is it low impact, like a tiny ant crawling through the back forty acres, where you don't even know of its existence. Does the person want to be open, grow and change? Or are they convinced they are always right, now and forever? Are they teachable or closed down? How novel is the concept? So new that they cannot begin to comprehend its reality? (Such as the natives who first saw Columbus' ships in the harbor and were convinced they didn't see them until the sailors were on their beach?) How many times has the message been repeated with authority? A commercial on TV watched a 1000 times or one tiny newsprint ad that you've seen only once? Does the item coordinate with your values and life purpose or is it antithetical to what you value and believe? (For instance I hate guns. I doubt any one could persuade me to buy and use one).

My answer is very simple. Society shapes the life of individuals in many, many ways. How their parents think and act, how their teachers think and act, how their friends, fellow students and fellow employees think and act, how their employers think and act, how other people in their community think and act, how their local, state and national governments think and act - all these are influenced by the society as a whole and in its separate parts. Of course there are some factors in the way individuals’ lives are shaped that are dependent on their genetic make-up, but even that is influenced by their social environment, because certain situations cause some genes to fire and some to remain dormant. Examples of this are seen clearly when people have to fight to defend their freedom, or flee from persecution or suffer the extreme dislocation of outright warfare. Immigration can also shape individuals to a lesser or greater extent, as they need to learn new skills in order to survive in the new country. I could go on and on, but I think that I have made my point. :-)

response.answer_text: One way is that it establishes what is considered to be “normal” or “desirable.” For example, in many societies in the United States, it is considered normal to be monolingual and desirable to be extroverted and emotionally strong. In many eastern (hemisphere) societies, however, normal would be speaking a couple of languages and desirable would include high sensitivity, deep thinking, and sometimes more reservedness. It also creates the norms of how one should act and not act.

Society is a system of organization. It is usually done via power, economics, socially, religiously, or militarily. Most societies are a mixture of the above. Depending on which predominates, will determine to a large extent, the horizons that lay in front of each individual. It takes a very strong and independent mind, to break loose from an overarching paradigm, such as the authoritarian system of Russia, or the economically driven one of America. Depending on which forces are supreme, will determine who the society is bent towards one goal or another.

response.answer_text: Because we are a species of social animals, we possess an innate need for acceptance, a need that impels us to behave in a way that facilitates coexistence. In other words, it isn’t so much society, but rather nature, that makes us want to go along with the group. The behaviors that the group endorses are somewhat of a moving target, and determined by the awareness of the masses.
